Reading List

Core texts and anchor papers by theme

Core Texts

  • (Hilpisch 2019)
    Module: FIN510, FIN720 ‚Äî Level: Foundation/Advanced
  • (Liaw 2021)
    Module: FIN720 ‚Äî Level: Foundation

Note: Additional industry books listed in the approved handbooks are useful for context. The lists below prioritise peer‚Äëreviewed academic articles to anchor analytical learning.

Theme Anchors (Articles)

Each theme lists 1‚Äì2 high‚Äëquality, widely cited papers. Tags indicate primary module and suggested level.

FinTech Landscape

  • (Philippon 2016)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)
  • (Vives 2019)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)

Modern Investment & Financial Inclusion

  • (Suri and Jack 2016)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)
  • (Mollick 2014)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)

Crypto Finance

  • (B"ohme et al. 2015)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)
  • (Howell, Niessner, and Yermack 2020)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)

Data Science for Finance

  • (Gu, Kelly, and Xiu 2020)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)
  • (Tetlock 2007)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)

Machine Learning (Advanced, FIN720)

  • (Chen, Pelger, and Zhu 2021)
    Module: FIN720 (Advanced)

  • (Gabaix et al. 2025)
    Module: FIN720 (Advanced)

AI & NLP in Finance

  • (Cao et al. 2023)
    Module: FIN510 (Advanced), FIN720 (Advanced)

Payments

  • (Ausubel 1991)
    Module: FIN720 (Foundation)
  • (Rysman 2009)
    Module: FIN720 (Foundation)

Open Finance (Open Banking, Blockchain, Smart Contracts)

  • (Catalini and Gans 2020)
    Module: FIN720 (Foundation)

Market Demand (Emerging Markets, Inclusion, Policy)

  • (Buchak et al. 2018)
    Module: FIN720 (Foundation)
  • (Suri and Jack 2016)
    Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)

Usage Notes

  • The readings above are deliberately selective and rigorous; they anchor each theme for both modules.
  • For FIN510, use them as guided readings (focus on concepts and evidence).
  • For FIN720, expect critical appraisal and application.
  • Coding work should link to methods in the papers (e.g., ML baselines, text sentiment, event study design).

References

Ausubel, Lawrence M. 1991. ‚ÄúThe Failure of Competition in the Credit Card Market.‚Äù American Economic Review. https://doi.org/10.2307/2006788.
B"ohme, Rainer, Nicolas Christin, Benjamin Edelman, and Tyler Moore. 2015. ‚ÄúBitcoin: Economics, Technology, and Governance.‚Äù Journal of Economic Perspectives. https://doi.org/10.1257/jep.29.2.213.
Buchak, Greg, Gregor Matvos, Tomasz Piskorski, and Amit Seru. 2018. ‚ÄúFintech, Regulatory Arbitrage, and the Rise of Shadow Banks.‚Äù Journal of Financial Economics. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jfineco.2018.03.011.
Cao, Sean, Wei Jiang, Baozhong Yang, and Alan L. Zhang. 2023. ‚ÄúHow to Talk When a Machine Is Listening: Corporate Disclosure in the Age of AI.‚Äù Review of Financial Studies 36 (9): 3603‚Äì42. https://doi.org/10.1093/rfs/hhad021.
Catalini, Christian, and Joshua S. Gans. 2020. ‚ÄúSome Simple Economics of the Blockchain.‚Äù Communications of the ACM. https://doi.org/10.1145/3359552.
Chen, Long, Markus Pelger, and Jason Zhu. 2021. ‚ÄúDeep Learning in Asset Pricing.‚Äù Review of Financial Studies. https://doi.org/10.1093/rfs/hhab069.

Gu, Shihao, Bryan Kelly, and Dacheng Xiu. 2020. ‚ÄúEmpirical Asset Pricing via Machine Learning.‚Äù Review of Financial Studies. https://doi.org/10.1093/rfs/hhaa009.
Hilpisch, Yves. 2019. Python for Finance. 2nd ed. O‚ÄôReilly Media. https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/python-for-finance/9781492024330/.
Howell, Sabrina T., Marina Niessner, and David Yermack. 2020. ‚ÄúInitial Coin Offerings: Financing Growth with Cryptocurrency Token Sales.‚Äù Review of Financial Studies 33 (9): 3925‚Äì74. https://doi.org/10.1093/rfs/hhz131.
Liaw, K. T. 2021. The Routledge Handbook of FinTech. Routledge. https://www.routledge.com/The-Routledge-Handbook-of-FinTech/Liaw/p/book/9780367339152.
Mollick, Ethan. 2014. ‚ÄúThe Dynamics of Crowdfunding: An Exploratory Study.‚Äù Journal of Business Venturing. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jbusvent.2013.06.005.
Philippon, Thomas. 2016. ‚ÄúThe FinTech Opportunity.‚Äù Working Paper w22476. National Bureau of Economic Research. https://www.nber.org/system/files/working_papers/w22476/w22476.pdf.
Rysman, Marc. 2009. ‚ÄúThe Economics of Two-Sided Markets.‚Äù Journal of Economic Perspectives. https://doi.org/10.1257/jep.23.3.125.
Suri, Tavneet, and William Jack. 2016. ‚ÄúThe Long-Run Poverty and Gender Impacts of Mobile Money.‚Äù Science. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aah5309.
Tetlock, Paul C. 2007. ‚ÄúGiving Content to Investor Sentiment: The Role of Media in the Stock Market.‚Äù Journal of Finance. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-6261.2007.01232.x.
Vives, Xavier. 2019. ‚ÄúDigital Disruption in Banking.‚Äù Annual Review of Financial Economics. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-financial-100719-120854.

# Theme Anchors (Articles)

Each theme lists 1‚Äì2 high‚Äëquality, widely cited papers. Tags indicate primary module and suggested level.

- [@philippon2016fintech]  
  Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)
- [@vives2019banking]  
  Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)

  Module: FIN510 (Foundation), FIN720 (Foundation)

# Usage Notes

- The readings above are deliberately selective and rigorous; they anchor each theme for both modules.  
- For FIN510, use them as guided readings (focus on concepts and evidence).  
- For FIN720, expect critical appraisal and application.  
- Coding work should link to methods in the papers (e.g., ML baselines, text sentiment, event study design).
